Graphical abstract Innovative heterostructures consist of Pd nanosheets and Pt nanoparticles, which exhibit efficient methanol electrooxidation performance owing to unique Pd@Pt heterointerface. Heterostructures have emerged as elaborate structures to improve catalytic activity owing to their combined surface and distinct inverse interface. However, fabricating advanced nanocatalysts with facet-dependent interface remains an unexploited and promising area. Herein, we render the controlled growth of Pt nanoparticles (NPs) on Pd nanosheets (NSs) by regulating the reduction kinetics of Pt2+ with solvents. Specifically, the fast reduction kinetic makes the Pt NPs uniformly deposited on the Pd NSs (U-Pd@Pt HS), while the slow reduction kinetic leads to the preferential growth of Pt NPs on the edge of the Pd NSs (E-Pd@Pt HS). Density functional theory calculations demonstrate that Pd (111)-Pt interface in U-Pd@Pt HS induces the electron-deficient status of Pd substrates, triggering the d-band center downshift and amplifying the Pd-Pt intermetallic interaction. The synergy between the electronic effect and interfacial effect facilitates the removal of poisonous intermediates on U-Pd@Pt HS. By virtue of the Pd NSs@Pt NPs interface, the heterostructure achieves exceptional methanol oxidation reaction activity as well as improved durability. This study innovatively proposes heterostructure engineering with facet-dependent interfacial modulation, offering instructive guidelines for the rational design of versatile heterocatalysts. Keywords Heterostructure engineering Facet-dependent interfacial modulation Methanol oxidation reaction 1 Introduction Noble metal nanocatalysts play a vital role in fuel cells, sensors, metal-air batteries, and electrocatalytic hydrogen generation owing to their abundant structural merits [1–5]. The rational design and development of high-performance noble metal nanocatalysts hold great prospects in these applications [6–8]. For property enhancement, structural regulation of noble metal nanocatalysts has been widely reported, as exemplified by the incorporation of transition metals, morphology engineering, phase control, and exposure of high-indexed facets [9–13]. Notably, the construction of heterostructures with inverse interfaces has aroused great interest due to their unique structural advantages and remarkable electrocatalytic properties [14–16]. As an emerging advanced strategy, heterostructure engineering has made considerable progress in diverse fields, such as catalysis, energy conversion and storage, and photoelectric devices [17–19]. For example, Chen and coworkers reported that Bi2O3/BiO2 heterojunction contributes to the enhanced adsorption of CO2 and intermediates, leading to high selectivity toward formate in the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction [20]. Xie and coworkers demonstrated that the RuO x -on-Pd heterostructure manifests remarkable electrocatalytic performance toward the oxygen reduction reaction since the inverse interface obtains charge from the Pd host and facilitates O–O bond cleavage [21]. As a robust nanostructure, heterostructures integrate the superiorities of charge redistribution, enhanced component interactions, and well-tailored electronic structure [22–25]. Although heterogeneous structures exhibit many advantages, the rational design and construction of heterostructured electrocatalysts remain persistent dilemmas. It is worth pointing out that the regulation over heterostructures is mostly focused on interface components, such as metal-oxide/hydroxide [26,27], metal-sulfide/phosphide [28–31], and metal-alloy [32,33]. However, the facet-dependent interface modulation has been seldom studied, although it offers a suitable structural model to investigate the synergy between metal and metal with different facets. Apart from constructing heterostructures, the rational design of nanocatalysts with applicable dimensions and components is of important significance to explore the correlation between the inverse interface and the catalytic properties. Two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials as substrates display highly open surfaces and a large number of edge sites with high surface energy, which are conducive to the introduction of foreign species and the construction of inverse interfaces [34]. In addition, the selection of components is a crucial issue because the differences in the lattice parameters of components will determine the mechanisms of crystal growth from thermodynamics [35]. On the premise of selecting components with small lattice mismatch (f), the epitaxial seed growth method makes the construction of heterostructures possible, such as Pt-Pd (f = 0.8%) [36], Cu-Au (f = 11.4%) [37], Pd-Cu (f = 7.1%) [38], and Au-Ag (f = 0.2%) [39]. The interactions between building blocks in heterostructures have been the focus of electrocatalyst research. In particular, Pd-Pt heterostructures system attracts extensive attention for their integrated superiorities in electron redistribution, active sites increasement, and stabilization toward electrochemical reactions. For example, Ren and co-workers reported that the isolated growth of Pt overlayer on the Pd nanocube surface leads to the enhanced hydrogen evolution activity, owing to the abundant reactive Pd/Pt heterointerfaces. However, the effect of Pd/Pt interface with specific crystal facets on catalytic performance is still largely unexplored to date. A key challenge is to precisely synthesize PdPt nanocatalysts with controllable interfacial facets. Motivated by the considerations above, Pd@Pt heterostructures with thermodynamic advantages were prepared by adjusting the reduction kinetics of Pt2+ with different solvents. Heterostructure engineering provides effective interfacial control of Pd@Pt nanocrystals, where enriched Pt nanoparticles (NPs) are deposited at different positions on 2D Pd nanosheets (NSs). The Pt NPs are distributed on the top/bottom surface and edge sites of the Pd NSs, corresponding to U-Pd@Pt HS and E-Pd@Pt HS. Noticeably, the synergistic effect beneath the interfacial structure significantly enhances the methanol oxidation reaction (MOR) performance. Pd@Pt heterostructures exhibit interfacial facets-dependent electrocatalytic performance. Specifically, the optimized U-Pd@Pt HS with Pd (111)-Pt interface shows a mass activity of 4.65 A mgPd+Pt −1, which is 2.7-fold, 2.4-fold, 2.0-fold, and 1.2-fold larger than that of Pd NS, Pd NSs + Pt NPs mixture, PdPt alloy, and E-Pd@Pt HS catalysts, respectively. The construction of the Pd@Pt heterostructure provides a robust reference for material design toward potential applications. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of PdPt alloy nanosheets, U-Pd@Pt HS, and E-Pd@Pt HS Pd NSs and PdPt alloy nanosheets were synthesized by a modified protocol reported by our group (see Supporting Information). The Pd NSs were collected through centrifugation and washed with an ethanol/acetone (V(acetone)/V(ethanol) = 9/1) mixture. Then, the Pd NSs dispersed in 10 mL benzyl alcohol were added into a flask and preheated at 100 °C for 10 min. In the synthesis of U-Pd@Pt HS, the Pt precursor solution dissolving 4.00 mg of Pt(acac)2 in 5.00 mL of oleylamine (OAM) was injected into the reaction flask, and the heating temperature was raised to 160 °C for 1 h. The synthesis of E-Pd@Pt HS was similar to that of U-Pd@Pt HS, except that Pt(acac)2 was dissolved in 2.00 mL of OAM and 3.00 mL of octadecene (ODE). The products were collected by centrifugation and then washed with an ethanol/cyclohexane (V(ethanol)/V(cyclohexane) = 5/1) mixture. 2.2 Characterizations Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was conducted on a HITACHI HT7700 transmission electron microscope at an accelerating voltage of 120 kV. High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) and high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) images were implemented by an FEI Tecnai F20 transmission electron microscope operated at 200 kV. An X’Pert-Pro MPD diffractometer (PANalytical, Netherlands) was used to collect the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to investigate the surface composition and elemental valence of the products. 2.3 Electrochemical tests A three-electrode system was used to implement the electrochemical measurements, consisting of a Pt wire (counter electrode), a glassy carbon electrode (GCE) (working electrode), and a saturated Hg/Hg2Cl2 (SCE) (reference electrode). All catalysts were mixed with isopropanol and Nafion (V/V = 1/0.005). 5 μL of catalyst ink (0.2 mg mL−1) was deposited on a GCE and dried naturally. The electrochemical active surface areas (ECSAs) were determined by CO stripping curves at 20 mV s−1 in 0.1 M HClO4. MOR performance tests were performed in 1 M KOH containing 1 M methanol at 50 mV s−1. The ECSA of the electrocatalyst was determined according to the following equation. ECSA = Q CO - adsorption / 420 × M metal M metal represents the metal loading, Q CO-adsorption is the charge for CO adsorption, and 420 (μC cm−2) represents the charge required to oxidize a monolayer adsorbed CO on metal surface. The activation energy of electrocatalysts within 273.15–303.15 K was determined by the Arrhenius equation. log j = log A - E a / ( 2.3 R T ) j represents the current density, R represents the gas constant, T represents the temperature, and E a represents the apparent activation energy. By linearly fitting log j and T −1, the slope represents E a. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physical characterization of the Pd@Pt heterostructure The Pd@Pt heterostructure was typically synthesized by the epitaxial seed growth method. First, Pd NS seeds were prepared according to a modified protocol reported by our group [40]. Pd NSs feature a 2D morphology and face-centered cubic (fcc) structure (Fig. S1 a and b), and atomic force microscopy (AFM) analysis reveals that the thickness of a single-layer nanosheet is approximately 5 nm (Fig. S2). In the second step, Pt2+ was reduced and deposited at different positions on the Pd NSs by regulating the reduction kinetics with solvents. The HAADF-STEM and TEM images show that U-Pd@Pt HS is composed of well-dispersed Pt NPs and Pd NSs (Fig. 1a and b). The average diameter of the Pt NPs is determined to be 8.1 nm (Fig. 1c), and the thickness of the nanosheets is similar to that of the Pd NSs (Fig. S3). The PXRD pattern (Fig. S4) of U-Pd@Pt HS exhibits obvious peaks corresponding to fcc Pd (JCPDS No. 87-0643) and Pt (JCPDS No. 87-0636). The HRTEM images of U-Pd@Pt HS show a lattice spacing of 0.232 nm, corresponding to the 1/3(422) reflections originating from the stacking faults of fcc palladium (Fig. 1d). Selected area electron diffraction also confirms the existence of 1/3(422) reflections (Fig. S5). Pt NPs exhibit an interplanar spacing of 0.227 nm, corresponding to the (111) facet of fcc platinum (Fig. 1e). The line-scan analysis (Fig. 1f) and elemental mapping images (Fig. 1g) of U-Pd@Pt HS demonstrate that Pt NPs are distributed on the Pd NSs, which exhibit random, uniform, and dense characteristics. Interestingly, by simply replacing the solvent OAM with the mixed solvent of OAM and ODE, we obtained a new type of Pd@Pt heterostructure (E-Pd@Pt HS). The morphology of the E-Pd@Pt HS is determined by HAADF-STEM and TEM images (Fig. 2 a and b), and the Pt NPs are deposited at the edge of the Pd NSs. The average diameter of Pt NPs in E-Pd@Pt HS is measured to be 6.6 nm (Fig. 2c). The Pd NSs and Pt NPs display lattice spacing of approximately 0.232 and 0.227 nm, respectively (Fig. 2d and e). The PXRD of E-Pd@Pt HS can be indexed to the fcc structure (Fig. S6), similar to that of U-Pd@Pt HS. The line-scan analysis (Fig. 2f) and elemental mapping images (Fig. 2g) of E-Pd@Pt HS intuitively show that the distribution of Pt NPs is not uniform and concentrated at the edge of the Pd NS. 3.2 Growth mechanism of the Pd@Pt heterostructure To reveal the formation mechanism of the Pd@Pt heterostructure, we first collected the intermediates at different reaction times and investigated the composition variation with reaction time. When the Pt precursor was dissolved in 5 mL OAM, the content of Pt rapidly increased to 9.2% within 5 min and eventually reached approximately 24% (Fig. S7). In contrast, when the Pt precursor was dissolved in 2 mL OAM + 3 mL ODE, the content of Pt slowly increased to 10.5% within 15 min and eventually reached approximately 16%. Based on the experimental results, we concluded that the reduction kinetics of the solvent might play an important role in the distribution of Pt NPs. To confirm this hypothesis, the reaction products at different OAM/ODE ratios were collected and systematically characterized. When ODE is dominant (ODE/OAM ≫ 1), the products are 2D nanosheets (Fig. 3 a and b). However, when ODE/OAM ≈ 1 or OAM is dominant (ODE/OAM ≪ 1), the products change from nanosheets to E-Pd@Pt HS (Fig. 3c and d) or U-Pd@Pt HS (Fig. 3e and f), respectively. Fig. 4 (a) shows the compositional evolution from nanosheets to two distinct Pd@Pt heterostructures, in which the content of Pt gradually increases. OAM and ODE are strong reducing agents and surface capping agents, respectively, corresponding to strong and weak reducing power [41]. The reduction kinetics varies with the amount of solvent. Under weak reaction kinetics, the deposition of Pt atoms was much slower than the surface diffusion of Pt (v deposition ≪ v diffusion), and the Pt atoms could be evenly spread across the surface, generating a homogeneous Pd-Pt alloy with a small amount of Pt (3.0% and 11.4%) [42,43]. With increasing reduction power, the deposition rate of Pt atoms was higher than the surface diffusion of Pt (v deposition > v diffusion), resulting in the local nucleation and growth of Pt along the active region of the (100) plane. In contrast, when the deposition of Pt atoms was much faster than the surface diffusion of Pt (v deposition ≫ v diffusion), most of the Pt2+ was reduced and evenly distributed around the Pd NSs. The structure and compositional evolution from the Pd-Pt alloy nanosheets to the Pd@Pt heterostructures reveal that a rapid reduction of Pt2+ leads to the random distribution of Pt NPs on the surface of the Pd NSs (Fig. 4b), and a slow reduction of Pt2+ results in the oriented growth of Pt NPs on the edge of the Pd NSs. The variant deposition position of Pt NPs determines the difference of interfacial structure. As shown in Fig. 4(c), U-Pd@Pt HS and E-Pd@Pt HS display the Pd (111)-Pt and Pd (100)-Pt interfaces, providing a platform to elucidate the promotion effect of facet-dependent interfacial structure on catalytic activity. 3.3 Electrochemical performance of the Pd@Pt heterostructure Considering the novel 2D Pd@Pt heterostructure, the electrochemical properties of MOR were investigated. In addition, PdPt alloy nanosheets (AS) were prepared as a reference for elucidating the interfacial effect on electrocatalytic performance. There are many similarities between U-Pd@Pt HS and PdPt AS, such as morphology, composition, and exposed crystal facets, except for the abundant interfaces in U-Pd@Pt HS (Fig. S8). Before the electrochemical tests, the electrocatalysts U-Pd@Pt HS/C, E-Pd@Pt HS/C, PdPt AS/C, Pd NSs/C, and Pd NSs + Pt NPs mixture/C were prepared by loading the products on carbon powder. The ECSAs for U-Pd@Pt HS/C, E-Pd@Pt HS/C, PdPt AS/C, Pd NS/C, PtRu/C, and Pd/C were calculated to be 89.6, 87.9, 58.8, 38.4, 47.3, and 49.8 m2 g−1, respectively, through the CO stripping curves in Fig. 5 (a) and Fig. S9(a). The heterostructure exhibited the highest ECSA value, implying that the introduction of inverse interfaces provides sufficient active sites for electrocatalytic reactions. The electrocatalytic properties for MOR were investigated by cyclic voltammetry (CV) in a 1 M KOH solution containing 1 M methanol. As shown in Fig. 5(b) and Fig. S9(b), U-Pd@Pt HS/C exhibits the optimal electrocatalytic performance among these catalysts. The electrocatalytic activities are closely correlated with the structure of nanocatalysts in the order of U-Pd@Pt HS/C > E-Pd@Pt HS/C > PdPt AS/C > Pd NS/C. In particular, U-Pd@Pt HS/C delivers the highest mass activity of 4.65 A mgPd+Pt −1 (Fig. 5c), which shows significant enhancement in comparison to E-Pd@Pt HS/C (3.81 A mgPd+Pt −1), PdPt AS/C (2.38 A mgPd+Pt −1), Pd NS/C (1.75 A mgPd −1), PtRu/C (0.41 A mgPt −1), and Pd/C (0.30 A mgPd −1) (Fig. S9c). Additionally, U-Pd@Pt HS/C also exhibits outstanding specific activity, reaching 5.19 mA cm−2 (Fig. 5d), which is 1.2-fold, 1.3-fold, 1.1-fold, 5.9-fold, and 8.6-fold larger than that of E-Pd@Pt HS/C, PdPt AS/C, Pd NS/C, PtRu/C, and Pd/C, respectively. To our knowledge, the obtained U-Pd@Pt HS/C shows remarkable activity for MOR among the reported Pd-based electrocatalysts (Fig. S10 and Table S1). Furthermore, the Pd NSs + Pt NPs mixture also was prepared and investigated for its electrocatalytic property toward MOR. As shown in Fig. S11, Pt NPs in mixture display average diameter of 7.0 nm, similar to that of U-Pd@Pt HS and E-Pd@Pt HS. Specifically, the mixture exhibits a mass activity of 1.96 A mgPd+Pt −1 and specific activity of 2.23 mA cm−2 (Fig. S12). Mixture shows the lower activity than U-Pd@Pt HS, which demonstrates the importance of Pd NSs@Pt NPs interface in MOR. The durability of the catalysts toward MOR was investigated by multiple CV and chronoamperometric (CA) tests. The prepared U-Pd@Pt HS/C and E-Pd@Pt HS/C possess superior stability after 1000 consecutive CV tests (Fig. 5e and Fig. S13). The mass activities could still reach 1.51 and 0.84 A mgPd+Pt −1 for U-Pd@Pt HS/C and E-Pd@Pt HS/C, far beyond that of PdPt AS/C, Pd NS/C, mixture, PtRu/C, and Pd/C (Fig. S14). After the CA tests, U-Pd@Pt HS/C retained excellent activity and structural integrity, while severe activity decay and aggregation occurred on Pd/C (Fig. 5f and Fig. S15). 3.4 Performance enhancement mechanism of the Pd@Pt heterostructure Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was employed to explore the electron transfer resistance during MOR. In general, the larger the diameter of the semicircle is, the greater the electron transfer resistance (R CT) is. The semicircular diameter for U-Pd@Pt HS/C and E-Pd@Pt HS/C in 1 M KOH solution containing 1 M methanol is much less than that of PdPt AS/C, Pd NS/C, mixture, PtRu/C, and Pd/C (Fig. S16), which suggests that the Pd NSs@Pt NPs interface functionally promotes the electron transport for MOR [44,45]. Information on the electrode-catalyst-electrolyte interface was further investigated through an equivalent circuit (inset of Fig. 6 a). The solution resistance (R S) was approximately 6.4 Ω, and U-Pd@Pt HS/C exhibits the smallest R CT, which is consistent with it having the highest electrooxidation activity toward MOR (Table S2). Additionally, CV measurements of all catalysts were performed with different scanning rates from 10 to 100 mV s−1 to investigate the reaction kinetics during MOR (Fig. 6b and Fig. S17). Fig. 6(b) displays the effect of the scan rate on the CV curves, where the current density (j) and peak potential increased with increasing scan rate. j is linear relation with the square root of the scanning rate (v 1/2), suggesting that the diffusion of reactants and intermediates is the rate-determining step [46,47]. As depicted in the plot of j versus v 1/2, U-Pd@Pt HS/C demonstrats a larger slope (0.32) than E-Pd@Pt HS/C (0.27), PdPt AS/C (0.17), and Pd/C (0.03), indicating that the boosted interfacial effect can effectively improve the reaction kinetics for MOR (Fig. 6c). In addition, the apparent activation energies (E a) of different catalysts were also investigated by Arrhenius plots [48,49]. As shown in Fig. 6(d) and Fig. S18, U-Pd@Pt HS/C delivers the lowest E a value among the tested catalysts, namely, the fastest reaction rate. Fig. 6(e) presents the surface valence band photoemission spectra of the aforementioned catalysts. The d-band center is an effective descriptor to predict the CO tolerance of electrocatalysts. Obviously, U-Pd@Pt HS/C and E-Pd@Pt HS/C show lower d-band centers than PdPt AS/C and Pd NS/C (Fig. S19). The downshift of the d-band center in the Pd@Pt heterostructures leads to the weakened binding strength of poisonous intermediates and thus improved catalytic performance [50,51]. It is a general belief that the electrocatalytic behavior of nanocatalysts is dependent on their electronic structures. Hence, XPS was used to investigate the structural evolution of the Pd-Pt system after the introduction of inverse interface. For U-Pd@Pt HS, two peaks with binding energies of 336.1 and 341.4 eV are assigned to the 3d 5/2 and 3d 3/2 orbitals of metallic Pd, respectively. The Pd 3d orbitals of U-Pd@Pt HS shift to a higher binding energy by 0.1 and 0.2 eV compared with that of E-Pd@Pt HS and PdPt AS, respectively (Fig. 7 a). Fig. 7(b) shows two peaks of Pt 4f orbitals, where the peaks at 71.16 and 74.56 eV are assigned to the 4f 7/2 and 4f 5/2 orbitals of metallic Pt. The Pt 4f peaks of U-Pd@Pt HS negatively shift by 0.14 and 0.29 eV compared to that of E-Pd@Pt HS and PdPt AS, respectively. The variations in binding energy demonstrate that the introduction of the Pd NSs@Pt NPs interface induces intense electron transfer from Pd to Pt, leading to an electron-deficient state of Pd [52–54]. As shown in Fig. 7(c–e) and Fig. S20, pure CO was purged into the electrolyte to further investigate the anti-poisoning ability of the electrocatalysts during the CA tests. The current density of PdPt AS/C and Pd/C dramatically decreased after the injection of CO, while the current density of the heterostructure sharply increased and then slowly decreased, indicating enhanced CO tolerance. As a result, we have demonstrated that the electron deficiency of Pd enables heterostructured electrocatalysts an outstanding anti-poisoning ability. 3.5 Density functional theory (DFT) calculation for interfacial structural analysis DFT calculations were performed to investigate the electronic interactions at the Pd NSs@Pt NPs interface and understand the performance promotion of Pd NSs@Pt NPs interface on MOR. Pt monolayer is coated on Pd (111) and Pd (100) substrates to simply simulate the interface structure (Fig. S21). Projected density of states (PDOS) of different surface is calculated to estimate the d-band center. As shown in Fig. 8 (a), the d-band center of Pd atoms around Pd(111)-Pt and Pd(100)-Pt interface shifts downward compared to Pd(111) and Pd(100) surface. It is well known that the work function (Φ) determines the direction of charge transfer in heterostructures [55–58]. During the formation of heterostructures, electrons are transferred from the component with low work function to the component with high work function, causing their Fermi levels to tend to the same value. To our knowledge, the work functions of Pt and Pd are 5.65 and 5.0 eV, respectively. The work function difference between Pd and Pt can drive electron transfer from Pd to Pt, resulting in electron depletion on the Pd substrate. Fig. 8(b and c) demonstrates the charge density difference in two types of interface structures, in which orange and green correspond to electron depletion and accumulation, respectively. It can be found that the electrons tend to transfer from Pd (100) or Pd (111) surface to the Pt monolayer. Charge analysis indicates that electron depletion in the Pd (111) is 0.38 e, while electron depletion in the Pd (100) is 0.21 e with the different interface. DFT calculations illustrate not only the effect of facet-dependent interfacial regulation on electronic structure, but also the electron deficiency state of Pd NSs neighboring Pt. Consequently, the synergistic effect in Pd@Pt heterostructures between the electronic effect and interfacial effect strengthens the resistance to poisonous CO species. On the one hand, XPS and DFT calculations have illustrated that the introduction of inverse interface regulates the electronic structure of the catalyst. The interactions between the Pd NSs and the Pt NPs endow Pd NSs with electron-deficient status, which benefits the oxidation of adsorbed methanol. On the other hand, the Pd NSs@Pt NPs interface plays a crucial role in improving the catalytic performance since it provides not only the channel for charge redistribution, but also the vicinity for intermediate spillover. To be specific, Pd NSs@Pt NPs interface provides more avenues to facilitate poisonous intermediates and electron transfer during the MOR, and thus achieves rapid removal of COads to accelerate the release of active site and subsequent adsorption of reactant. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we designed and implemented two types of Pd@Pt heterostructures by altering the reduction kinetics. DFT calculations demonstrate that Pd (111)-Pt interface in U-Pd@Pt HS induces more obvious electron-deficient status of Pd substrates, compared with Pd (100)-Pt interface in E-Pd@Pt HS, leading to the lower d-band center and excellent CO tolerance. Consequently, the optimized U-Pd@Pt HS realizes a top-ranked MOR activity and outstanding long-term stability, superior to the counterpart E-Pd@Pt HS and the PdPt AS without interfacial structure. This work shows a new direction of heterostructure engineering, lightening the design of efficient nanocatalysts for electrocatalysis and beyond. coredata.dc:description: Heterostructures have emerged as elaborate structures to improve catalytic activity owing to their combined surface and distinct inverse interface. However, fabricating advanced nanocatalysts with facet-dependent interface remains an unexploited and promising area. Herein, we render the controlled growth of Pt nanoparticles (NPs) on Pd nanosheets (NSs) by regulating the reduction kinetics of Pt2+ with solvents. Specifically, the fast reduction kinetic makes the Pt NPs uniformly deposited on the Pd NSs (U-Pd@Pt HS), while the slow reduction kinetic leads to the preferential growth of Pt NPs on the edge of the Pd NSs (E-Pd@Pt HS). Density functional theory calculations demonstrate that Pd (111)-Pt interface in U-Pd@Pt HS induces the electron-deficient status of Pd substrates, triggering the d-band center downshift and amplifying the Pd-Pt intermetallic interaction. The synergy between the electronic effect and interfacial effect facilitates the removal of poisonous intermediates on U-Pd@Pt HS. By virtue of the Pd NSs@Pt NPs interface, the heterostructure achieves exceptional methanol oxidation reaction activity as well as improved durability. This study innovatively proposes heterostructure engineering with facet-dependent interfacial modulation, offering instructive guidelines for the rational design of versatile heterocatalysts.
